{{globalize|date=September 2018}} This '''list of playing card nicknames''' has some [[nickname]]s for the [[playing card]]s in a 52-card deck, as used in some common card games, such as [[poker]]. {{wiktionarycat|type=Poker|category=Poker}}

===One-eyed royals=== The phrase '''one-eyed royals''' is jargon referring to the three face cards showing only one eye: the Jack of Spades ({{cards|J♠}}), Jack of Hearts ({{cards|J♥}}) and King of Diamonds ({{cards|K♦}}). The terminology results from the depiction of the face on the card as being shown in profile, so only one eye is visible (all other face cards show two eyes). The jacks are also referred to, separately, as '''one-eyed jacks''': Jack of Spades ({{cards|J♠}}), Jack of Hearts ({{cards|J♥}}).
They are frequently used in home games of [[draw poker]] as wildcards. Because the King of Diamonds is the only king card bearing an axe (the others show swords), a common phrase for the one-eyed royals is "One-eyed Jacks, the Man with the Axe". Another common phrase is "One-eyed Jacks and Suicide King" denoting the King of Hearts ({{cards|K♥}}) bearing a sword through his head. These four cards are the only cards of differing rank and [[Suit (cards)|suit]] in a common [[Deck (cards)|deck]] that share an identifying trait. Apart from the bedside Queen (of Spades), of course. She is the only one with a symbol beside her which looks a little like an old-fashioned wooden bedpost.
==Texas hold 'em pocket card nicknames== The following is a list of nicknames for pairs of two playing cards, usually hole cards, used in poker derivatives such as [[Texas hold 'em]] and [[Omaha hold 'em]] poker. These nicknames are usually used by the player when announcing their hand or by spectators or commentators who are watching the game. <!-- IF YOU CANNOT EDIT THE TABLE CORRECTLY, JUST POST YOUR ADDITION IN THE DISCUSSION TAB AND SOMEONE WHO CAN, WILL --> <!-- ENTRIES SHOULD ALL BE ALPHABETICAL -->

Tin<ref name="donkiedup"/>||From [[Rin Tin Tin]] K9 cop |- |The Doctor Who||K-9, the Robotic Dog from the British Television Series Doctor Who |- |Sawmill||[[Byron Wolford|Byron 'Cowboy' Wolford]] says: :''Milton Butts and I were playing poker in Bryan, Texas, where they had a good game going on the weekends. We'd been playing for a couple of days when a hand came up in which I had a K-9. I made a pretty good hand with it, but lost the pot and went broke. As I was driving back home to [[Houston]] with Milton, feeling kind of disgusted about going broke with that K-9, we passed by a sawmill where a man was sawing logs in the lumberyard. "As hard as that guy works for his money, I'll bet he would never go broke with a K-9", I told Milton. And that's how K-9 got named "Sawmill." Some of those names are still going around – [[Doyle Brunson]] mentioned the sawmill hand in his book, [[Super/System]]''<ref name="Wolford1">{{cite web |last='Cowboy' Wolford |first=Byron |authorlink=Byron Wolford |title=Aimsworth, Sawmill, and Everett |publisher=Card Player Magazine Volume 15, Number 24 |date=2002-11-22 |url=https://admin.corp.cardplayer.com/author/article/all/71/3836 |accessdate=2009-01-01 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} </ref> |- |align="center" rowspan="3"| K8 |Kate||A [[portmanteau]] of "''K''ing" and "Eight''"<ref name="TexasHoldem"/> |- |Feast||What the 'King ate'<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Kokomo||Imitative<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |align="center" rowspan="2"| K7 |[[Columbia River#Fish migration|Columbia River]]||The [[Columbia River]] is famous for its salmon runs. A player may only double down on his first two cards dealt. When a player doubles down, the original bet is automatically doubled (a second chip appears) and the player receives one more card.<ref>{{cite web |last = bwin.com |title = Lucky 7 Blackjack |url = https://help.bwin.com/Casino/InstantPlayCasino/Card_Games/Lucky7_Blackjack.aspx |accessdate = 2008-12-02 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090124043245/http://help.bwin.com/Casino/InstantPlayCasino/Card_Games/Lucky7_Blackjack.aspx |archive-date = 2009-01-24 |url-status = dead }}</ref> Since there are more 10 point cards than any other, doubling down is most worthwhile on an 11-point hand, 7-4 being worth 11 points. |- |Ghost Dog<ref name="TellPoker"/>||Almost undoubtedley from the film [[Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai]] starring [[Forest Whitaker]], but no explanation found |- |Kalashnikov||Most likely refers to the famous [[AK-47]] and [[AK-74]] assault rifles designed by [[Mikhail Kalashnikov]] |- |align="center" rowspan="3"| 73 |Dutch Waiter||Sven with a Tray |- |[[Joe Hachem]] || Joseph Hachem won the 2005 World Series main event holding {{cards|7♣|3♠}} when the flop came {{cards|4♦|5♦|6♥}}<ref name="flapokertours"/> |- |Swedish Busboy||Sven with a Tray, see also San Francisco Busboy and Dutch Waiter<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |align="center" rowspan="4"| 72 |Beer Hand (offsuit)||It's called the [[Beer Hand]] because it's either time for a beer; or if you win with this you need to get other players a beer; or only a person full of beers would play this hand.<ref name="flapokertours"/> The beer hand has the worst chance of winning of all possible pocket cards in a full table playing Texas Hold'em. It is slightly better in short-handed games because the fact that it is not possible to make a straight or flush without hitting four appropriate community cards is less important in short-handed games.<ref>{{cite web | last = Casino City | title = Definition of Beer Hand | url = http://dictionary.pokerzone.com/Beer+Hand | accessdate = 2009-02-02}} </ref> |- |Hammer (offsuit)<ref name="EPT51">{{cite episode | title = Pokerstars.com EPT London Highrollers | episodelink = European Poker Tour season 5 results | series = European Poker Tour | serieslink = European Poker Tour season 5 results | airdate = 2008-12-27 | season = 5 | number = 1}}</ref>||The Hammer isn't specifically the 72 hand. At least not officially. In poker, the hammer is defined as the last position (the cut-off), particularly when you're heads-up. The 72 offsuit got the nickname as a result of a competition to play "The Hammer" on "The Hammer" and has been adopted into legitimate Oxford Dictionary poker parlance<ref name="PokerGrub">{{cite web | last = Grubby | title = Poker Grub | date = 2004-04-09 | url = http://pokergrub.com/hammer.html | accessdate = 2009-01-14}} </ref> |- |W.H.I.P. (offsuit)||Worst Hand In Poker<ref name="Supe"/> |}

He used to play 63 as an ambush hand<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Jimmy Summerfield (offsuit)||Kevin Larsen says: :''One time while playing with Jimmy, she [the dealer] had noticed that trash cards were hitting the flop quite often especially 6's and 3's, so Jimmy wins a huge pot after she told him to play the 63 off he was holding. Thus was born the "Jimmy Sommerfield".'' :''Once, while playing down on the coast, a player wins a big pot. He slaps his cards down on the table and announces "I've got a Jimmy Somerfield!". Then Jimmy says "Let me introduce myself", and shows the player his ID.'' :''I was dealing a four eight game one night to Jimmy, a few other dealers and a bunch of locals. A fairly loose game. The pot is capped six or eight way action. Jimmy announces preflop "I've got my hand !" Nobody believes him when the flop comes 6 6 3 He gets four or five callers to the river. Monster Pot!''<ref name="Smiley">{{cite web | last = Larsen | first = Kevin | title = Poker Slang | url = http://www.angelfire.com/ms/yelims/.html | accessdate = 2009-01-03}}/</ref> |- |Spanish Inquisition||Nickname given to this starting hand by Iron Men of Poker. Refers to the fact that "[[The Spanish Inquisition (Monty Python)|Nobody Expects the Spanish Inquisition]]", a reference to the classic [[Monty Python]] quote.<ref name="IMOP">{{cite web | last = allvegaspoker.com | title = Poker Slang | url = http://www.allvegaspoker.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=17&t=12085&start=20&st=0&sk=t&sd=a | accessdate = 2011-06-03}}</ref> |- |align="center" rowspan="1"| 62 |Aimsworth||[[Byron Wolford|Byron 'Cowboy' Wolford]] says: :''I was in San Antone playing a big no-limit game with [[Jack Straus]], [[Red Berry (Texas politician)|Sen. Red Berry]], and a bunch of the old-time players. Jack was on top of you all the time, but in full ring games, he wasn't as tough as he was shorthanded or heads up. He had two aces and I took the flop with a 6-2. A deuce came on the flop, he made a bet, and I called him. Off came another deuce on the turn, he bet, and I called him. A third deuce came on the river and we got all in. When I showed him that 6-2, he said, "What the hell were you drawing at there, Cowboy?"'' :''"Oh, I wasn't drawing at nothing", I answered. "Just aiming at another deuce. I guess I'm Aimsworth."''<ref name="Wolford1"/> |- |}
===Five higher card=== {| class="wikitable" ! Card Initials !! Alternative Name !! Explanation |- |align="center" rowspan="5"| 55 |[[Sammy Hagar]]||After Hagar's song, "I Can't Drive 55"<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Nickels||Five cents per nickel<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Presto||There is debate as to where this term originated. The most commonly accepted source of the nickname is that many years ago, before Rec.gambling<ref>{{cite web|url=http://groups.google.com/group/rec.gambling.poker/topics|title=Google Groups|publisher=}}</ref> was split into several groups, followers of the group who were [[blackjack]] players were fond of saying "Presto!" as they turned up a 21. This became a sign of recognition of fellow travelers. Around this time (circa 1991), the World Rec Gambling Poker Tournament(WRGPT), of which the first few were played slowly over email, came into being. During WRGPT2(92-93), the attribution of pocket fives as the "Presto Hand" was made by the player Howard Simonson, after using pocket fives to knock out several players from the tournament some number of times. [If a copy of the table-talk from WRGPT2 can be found and cited, this can be absolutely confirmed] Consequently, the term stuck among the rec.gambling minions, and has become a common poker term today.<ref>{{cite newsgroup | title = Presto! | author = foldem | date = 2003-05-14 | newsgroup = rec.gambling.poker | url = http://groups.google.com/group/rec.gambling.poker/browse_thread/thread/6a04a35b791714f7/481de7999cc1cf85?#481de7999cc1cf85 | accessdate = 2008-11-29}} </ref> There is also suggestion that the hand won more often than it should due to a computer glitch.<ref name="xanadu"/> However, there is a counter-argument that there used to be a club in London called the Presto Club. The address was 55 [[Victoria, London|Victoria Street]], London. Therefore, whenever someone was dealt 55 in hold'em, they'd say they were dealt "Presto", because of the club's street address. When English players played events worldwide, the word spread, and it caught on everywhere.<ref>{{cite newsgroup | title = Presto! | author = Andrew Lacey | date = 2003-05-14 | newsgroup = rec.gambling.poker | url = http://groups.google.com/group/rec.gambling.poker/browse_thread/thread/6a04a35b791714f7/481de7999cc1cf85?#481de7999cc1cf85 | accessdate = 2008-11-29}} </ref> |- |- Wheelchairs>| looksl like 2 wheel chairs |Snakes<ref name="xanadu"/>||Looks like two snakes |- |Speed Limit||55 MPH,<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> the maximum speed limit in the US in the [[National Maximum Speed Law]] era |- |align="center" rowspan="3"| 54 |Colt 45||The gun, and the beer<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |[[Jesse James]]||Because the outlaw was rumored to have been shot by a .45<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Moneymaker||Winning hand of [[Chris Moneymaker]], 2003 [[World Series of Poker]] Main Event champion<ref name="flapokertours"/> |- |align="center" rowspan="2"| 53 |Bully Johnson||A poker player that [[Doyle Brunson]] described as being "laid back and quiet". He played this hand after being raised preflop and caught a straight on the flop to beat another guy's trip aces<ref name="TexasHoldem"/> |- |Juggernaut||Well-known ''[[Magic: The Gathering]]'' artifact card with power of five and toughness of three. |- |align="center" rowspan="6"| 52 |Bomber||[[B-52 Stratofortress|B-52 bomber]]<ref name="flapokertours"/> |- |Pick-up||As in [[52 Pickup|52 card pick up]]<ref name="flapokertours"/> |- |Quarter||25 cents<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Two Bits||25 cents<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |-
|Ivey||Named for one of the greatest bluffs on High Stakes Poker, when [[Phil Ivey]] raised pre-flop with a five-deuce offsuit, was re-raised by [[Lex Veldhuis]] with KJ suited, and then went all in causing Lex to fold his hand. |}
===Four higher card=== {| class="wikitable" ! Card Initials !! Alternative Name !! Explanation |- |align="center" rowspan="12"| 44 |- |Sailboats || The fours look like sails on a boat. |- |Obama || [[Barack Obama]] is the 44th President of the United States |- |Dark Force ({{cards|4♠|4♣}})||Dark Side Of The Fours<ref name="flapokertours"/> |- |Darth Vader ({{cards|4♠|4♣}})||The two black fours are the [[Dark side (Star Wars)|"Dark Side of the Fours"]]<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |[[Diana Dors]]||Her top measurement<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |The Harley ({{cards|4♠|4♣}})||Favorite hand of BCP pro Harley Quin after flopping quads with these hole cards: "The Fours are strong with this one..." |- |Luke Skywalker||"May the Fours be with you." He always said he played it ''On Principle'' |- | The Answer || In ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]'', the computer decided that [[List of phrases from The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy#Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything (42)|the answer to everything in the universe]] was 42<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |}
===Three higher card=== {| class="wikitable" ! Card Initials !! Alternative Name !! Explanation |- |align="center" rowspan="3"| 33 |Crabs||Because a 3 looks like it has pincers<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |Lucky Dragon||Favorite chinese hand that "never loses" |- |Treys||"Trey" dates back to the 14th century, and is a name for a card or a [[Dice|die]] showing three points; originally from [[Old French]] ''treis''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/trey|title=Definition of TREY|publisher=}}</ref> |- |align="center" rowspan="8"| 32 |- |Can of Corn<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/>||This nickname likely comes from baseball where a "[[List of baseball jargon (C)#can of corn|Can of Corn]]" is an easily caught [[List of baseball jargon (F)#fly ball|fly ball]]. Supposedly comes from a general store clerk reaching up and dropping a can from a high shelf.<ref>{{cite web | last = Jim | title = The Phrase Finder: Re: Can of corn | date = 2001-11-01 | url = http://www.phrases.org.uk/bulletin_board/11/messages/625.html | accessdate = 2009-03-17}} </ref> Likely to be analogized due to the ease in which 32 is caught since it is the lowest possible non-hand (22 being a pair). |- |Little Pete<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/>||No explanation found |- |The Diaper<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/>||”The Dirty Diaper” if offsuit. |- |[[Michael Jordan]]||From his jersey number (23)<ref name="PokerNews"/> |- |- |Polish Big Slick||A bad Polish joke mimicking AK Big Slick<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |- |The Nut Low<ref>{{cite episode | title = Poker Nations Cup 2008 | episodelink = PartyGaming | series = Poker Nations Cup | airdate = 2008-10-07 | number = 5}} </ref>||In this instance 'nut' meaning 'most' rather than 'best', low hand (i.e., the lowest hand) |- |Hooter Hand (suited)||Named after famous poker dealer Houth "Hooter" Houn who played this hand as aggressively as AK. |- |Crubs (if clubs)||From the card game Hearts<ref name="HoldemSecrets"/> |}

==Poker hand nicknames== The following sets of playing cards can be referred to by the corresponding names in card games that include sets of three or more cards, particularly [[Draw Poker|3 and 5 card draw]], [[Texas Hold 'em]] and [[Omaha Hold 'em]]. The nicknames would often be used by players when revealing their hands, or by spectators and commentators watching the game. With TV and web broadcasting of Poker tournaments, nicknames became much more popular all over the world.

==Notes== {{note|9h}}The nine of diamonds playing card is often referred to as the [[Curse of Scotland]]<ref>{{cite book | last = Pynchon | first = Thomas | authorlink = Thomas Pynchon | title = [[Against the Day]] | publisher = Vinatege | year = 2007 | pages = 26}}</ref> or the '''Scourge of Scotland''',<ref>{{cite web|last=Online Casino Digital |title=Scourge of Scotland Poker |year=2006 |url=http://www.onlinecasino-digital.com/gamblingwords/scourgeofscotland-poker/index.html |accessdate=2009-02-12 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061107161110/http://www.onlinecasino-digital.com/gamblingwords/scourgeofscotland-poker/index.html |archivedate=November 7, 2006 }}</ref> there are a number of reasons given for this connection: # It was the playing card used by [[John Dalrymple, 1st Earl of Stair|Sir John Dalrymple]], the [[Earl of Stair]], to cryptically authorise the [[Massacre of Glencoe|Glencoe Massacre]].{{citation needed|date=June 2016}} Certainly there is a resemblance between the nine of diamonds and his coat of arms. # [[Prince William, Duke of Cumberland|The Duke of Cumberland]] is supposed to have scribbled the order for "no quarter" to be given after the [[Battle of Culloden]] on a nine of diamonds playing card. # It has also been suggested that it is a misreading of the "Corse of Scotland" i.e., the "[[Flag of Scotland|Cross of Scotland]]" or [[Saint Andrew|St Andrew's]] [[Saltire]]. There is a resemblance between the pattern of the nine of diamonds and the Saltire. # Nine diamonds were at one time stolen from the [[crown of Scotland]] and a tax was levied on the Scottish people to pay for them – the tax got the nickname "The Curse of Scotland".<ref>{{cite web | last = RampantScotland.com | title = Did You Know? – Curse of Scotland | url = http://www.rampantscotland.com/know/blknow_curse.htm | accessdate = 2009-02-11}} </ref> # The game of Comète being introduced by [[Mary of Guise|Mary of Lorraine]] (alternatively by [[James II of England|James, Duke of York]]) into the court at [[Holyrood Palace|Holyrood]], the Nine of Diamonds, being the winning card, got this name in consequence of the number of courtiers ruined by it. # In the [[Pope Joan (card game)|game of Pope Joan]], the Nine of Diamonds is the Pope – a personage whom some Scottish [[Presbyterianism|Presbyterians]] consider as a curse. # Diamonds imply royalty and every ninth [[List of Scottish monarchs|king of Scotland]] was a curse to his country.<ref>{{cite book | last = Chambers | first = Robert | authorlink = Robert Chambers (publisher born 1802) | title = The Book of Days: A Miscellany of Popular Antiquities in Connection with the Calendar, Including Anecdote, Biography, & History, Curiosities of Literature and Oddities of Human Life and Character, Vol I | publisher = W & R Chambers | year = 1864 | pages = 75 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=q24oAAAAYAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=the+book+of+days#PPA75,M1}}</ref>
{{note|6h}}The Six of Hearts is known as '''loyalty at the risk of death''' or '''Grace's Card'''. This is because in 1688 an Irish [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] soldier, Colonel [[Richard Grace]] of Moynelly House, [[Athlone]], used this card to write a refusal to surrender and sent it to [[William III of England|William of Orange]]. Colonel Grace was loyal to [[James II of England|King James II of England]], and risked being shot or hanged for his refusal to give up. The words Colonel Grace wrote were, "Tell your master I despise his offer, and that honor and conscience are dearer to a gentleman than all the wealth and titles a prince can bestow"<ref>{{cite book | last = Leeming | first = Joseph | title = Games and Fun with PLaying Cards | publisher = Dover Publications | date = 1980-03-01 | pages = 3 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=FDH1huAGSTkC&pg=PA2&lpg=PA2#PPA3,M1| isbn = 9780486239774 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Chambers | first = Robert | authorlink = Robert Chambers (publisher born 1802) | title = The Book of Days: A Miscellany of Popular Antiquities in Connection with the Calendar, Including Anecdote, Biography, & History, Curiosities of Literature and Oddities of Human Life and Character, Vol II | publisher = W & R Chambers | year = 1832 | pages = 781 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=K0UJAAAAIAAJ&pg=RA1-PA781&lpg=RA1-PA781&dq=Tell+your+master+I+despise+his+offer,+and+that+honor+and+conscience+are+dearer+to+a+gentleman+than+all+the+wealth+and+titles+a+prince+can+bestow#PPP1,M1}}</ref>
{{note|Wheel}}The origin of '''The Bicycle''', '''Little Wheel''', '''Spoke''', '''Steel Wheel''', '''Steel Wheeled Bike''' or simply '''The Wheel''' is unknown, but it is believed to have something to do with the popular [[Bicycle Playing Cards]] issued by the [[United States Playing Card Company]].<ref>{{cite web | last = Casino City | title = Definition of Steel Wheel | date = 2009-01-01 | url = http://dictionary.pokerzone.com/Steel+Wheel | accessdate = 2009-02-06}} </ref><ref>{{cite web | first = Shirley | last = Rosario | title = Wheel Poker Term – What is a Wheel? | url = }} </ref>
{{note|Leia}} The '''Princess Leia''' is the hand AA23 (more common in [[Omaha hold 'em|Omaha]] since this version of poker used 4 hole cards){{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}. This is because [[Princess Leia|Leia]] was held prisoner in detention block AA23 before she was rescued by [[Han Solo|Han]], [[Chewbacca]] and [[Luke Skywalker|Luke]] in ''[[Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope]]''.<ref>{{cite web | last = Milmo | first = Cahal | last2 = Willetts | first2 = Tom | title = 23 fascinating facts about the number twenty-three | date = 2007-02-23 | url = http://afgen.com/number23g.html | accessdate = 2009-03-21}} </ref>
